Yes <@U1KSR4JP3> .  Once you calculate the manhattan distance for each value, there should be one closest one.  That's the nearest neighbor and your first prediction.
Then, the 3 closest ones get averaged together to make your second and final prediction
I understand that part. I’m talking about XX(transpose)…. sorry I think it should be a separate problem but it doesn’t have a number
I'm in the same boat <@U1KSR4JP3>
The new matrix should have 1's and 0's in the spots where they're in common or not.
So for example, if you calculate the matrix, entry 5,6 and 6,5 are both ones, signifying that person 5 and person 6 share the same attribute, which in this case is 'other'
So those two observations are similar to each other
ahh.. yeah that makes sense. Hopefully I'll remember for tomorrow!
thanks <@U1L6YQUSU>
so are you just looking for the people that share 1s?
You're creating a matrix that tells whether or not people are similar.  So 3,6 and 6,3 are zeros, which also tells you something about them
so it's not just 1's,
oohhhhhh. just to make sure I have this right: If I’m looking at the relationship between person 3 and person 4…. I look at 3,4 and 4,3 in the matrix and see if they share the same value?
yeah that sounds right <@U1KSR4JP3>
Well, they'll always share the same value because the matrix is symmetric
You just want to know if that value is a zero or a one
So you can decide if they share a characteristic/how far apart they are
so lets look at person 1 and person 5
(which you can do by looking at 1,5 or 5,1)...
yep
giving a 0 for (1,5) and a 0 for (5,1)
so they would be considered far apart
Yes

when looking at the solutions on the google drive… they just subtracted a matrix of all 1s.
So the '1' in the spot tells you they're the same, but you'd want a '0' to represent the distance.  so you could take  abs(1-matrix) and get the right thing

<@U1KSR1MS4|rocky_chen> has joined the channel
can anyone explain why the impurity of the parent node is 35/80 and not 45/80 in question 7 of the CART worksheet?
Where does it say 35/80?
On the answer sheet.
And it's highlighted in RED!!!
Which I think means it was a correction.
<@U1L3G0YRJ|emmyburnett> has joined the channel
does anybody know 3c for the Model Assessment Measures?
misclassification rate for the M&M predictions
thanks
The explanation on the answer guide is good
But why not use 56%?
Which is 45/80

<@U1KRSV7AN> I think because (according to wikipedia) the impurity is the probability that randomly chosen element would be misclassified.  That root node would label everything as a Yes or T=1, so 35/80 would be misclassified.
I think

<@U1L3PU7BJ> the gain is the difference in purity between the parent node and the "winning" leaf. since the winning leaf gives oyu 100% purity, the gain = the number of NOs in the parent node, which is 35/80
why the number of NOs and not the number of YESes?
Because the NOs are what would be guessed incorrectly in the parent node
Becuase what you LOSE in impurity (i.e. gain in purity) by going with the 100% split is the impurity = NOs

<@U1L3PU7BJ> it confused me a bit too-- it's easy to justify it as the opposite rationally-- it seems like the gain would be the difference between 100% and the purity, so 45%, right? But you have to think about it as what you're actually GAINING. You are gaining 35% of incorrect observations, which would now be correct.
why are NOs incorrect? Are you assuming that T=1 is what you want?  What I'm trying to ask is how could you tell, with no context in this question, that T=0 wasn't what you wanted
i'm all out of WHACK

You want the split that gives you the best gain in purity <@U1L3PU7BJ>.  Of the 3 choices, X is the clear winner because  you basically gain all the purity.  X has 'yes' as everything, so that's why you want T=1

<@U1L6YQUSU>: I think what Diego is asking is how do you measure the impurity of the parent node - in this case it could either be 35/80 or 45/80. How do you know which one to use when measuring a gain in purity?
That's actually a good point. I had assumed 1 is what we "want", but didn't question that assumption.
Aren't they mathematically the same?  Is that why we're having this discussion?

<@U1KRNHQA1|pavalent> has joined the channel

Hope this helps:

Since the question asks us to calculate gains in MISCLASSIFICATION RATE, we use the formula: classification error = 1 - Maximum of (p(i|t))

Therefore, the classification error (which is our measure of impurity in this case) can not be greater than 50% (so 45/80 would be out of the question). In the case of classification error, having a 50% chance is as impure as it can get.

This image from the slide shows the limit of the misclassification error:
So if there were 60 of T=0 and 40 of T=1, the measure of impurity using the misclassification rate would be 40%
And if there were 40 of T=0 and 60 of T=1, the measure of impurity using misclassification rate would still be 40%
